Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 04:31PM Welga wrote: Here in Quebec Avastin is not yet approved for breast cancer so this is one. There was a report on TV of a woman who it was helping but she was going in debt just to be able to buy it and I think it cost here 12000$ a month so she could stay alive. Everything else had failed. Here it is only approved for colon cancer.  Also I know you mean well Beesie but I had to wait a month for my pathalogie repor, so for waiting times you cannot say Canada because, here in Quebec reports take time and are nerve consuming. I am not saying we do not have good hospitals here but sometimes I envy some of my neighbors as far as waiting and other issues.  Welga

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 10:50PM Welga wrote: Marylou, From reading in this forum lost of women got operated for carpal syndrome in their hands and their oncs continued them on Arimidex. Also from reading here Arimidex is more help in fighting BC than chemo. Maybe you should try Femara I had to switch Arimidex made me fell like I had the flue. Some supplements also help to reduce the aches, magnesium citrate, fish oil and others. Take a look at the thread ''Hormonal Therapy-before-during-after'' it might help you and you could get good advice on coping with the AI. Good luck and don't give up on such a great drug (besides the side effects of course)  Welga

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 02:03PM - edited Apr 12, 2011 02:07PM by Welga Kate Melatonine at first can give you nightmares and vivid dreams , It did to me, I started with 3 mg and after about a week I did not have them anymore, your body ajust. After you can if you need add 1 mg per week and find your right amount. They are a bit like antidepressant in the sense that the 1rs week is the hardest then your body gets used to it. If 3mg is too strong start with a lower dose, it really works, good luck, Welga

Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: May 26, 2010 12:41PM Welga wrote: Barbe, Yes WTF that must have been horible I could not stand that pain!!!!!! ridiculous. I was never offered a mammo since my bilateral masectomy, I would not accept it, if I ever find a lump I think I would call every hospital around to see if I can get one that will do only the ultrasound. What good is looking at only a piece of 1/2'' of skin. Incredible. Here we have several doctros that went private and are out of the system and some of them take patients for only one consult even if they never had them before. I guess walk in clinics are not an option if they are congested like ours. Don't give up, it's a hasell but for your own peace of mind. Sometimes what I did also is book myself for a mamo (when I had breast) even though I did not have the doctor's refence yet telling them I had one, since we only got to show them when we go to the appointment, so that made a shorter wait. Welga
